prompt: SI unit of electric current is:
explanation: Ampere (A) is the SI base unit of electric current.
V = I R (voltage = current × resistance).
Resistance is measured in ohm (Ω).

prompt: Resistance R of a wire: R ∝
explanation: R = ρ L/A; resistance proportional to length, inversely to area.
ρ = R A/L; unit Ω·m.

prompt: When resistors are in series, total R =
explanation: Series: R_eq = R1 + R2 + ...
Parallel: 1/R_eq = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + ...

answers: VI or I^2 R or V^2/R
explanation: P = V I = I^2 R = V^2/R.
Electrical power is in watts (W).
Current is flow of charge; in metals, electrons.

answers: Opposite to electron flow (positive to negative)
explanation: Conventional current: direction of flow of positive charge.

answers: Protect circuit (melts when current too high)
explanation: Fuse breaks circuit when current exceeds rating.

answers: Energy per unit charge supplied by source (voltage)
explanation: EMF = work done per unit charge (in volts).

answers: Terminal voltage < EMF when current flows
explanation: V_terminal = E - I r (r = internal resistance).

prompt: In parallel connection of cells (same EMF), total EMF =
answers: Same as one cell (current capacity increases)
explanation: Parallel: same voltage; current capacity adds.

prompt: In series connection of cells, total EMF =
explanation: Series: EMFs add.
Below T_c, resistance becomes zero.
More lattice vibrations → more scattering → R increases.
More thermal excitation → more charge carriers → R decreases.

answers: Ohmic conductors (e.g. metals at constant T)
explanation: V ∝ I only for ohmic materials (constant R).

answers: Sum of currents in = sum out at a junction
explanation: Sum of currents entering = sum leaving (charge conservation).

answers: Sum of potential differences around closed loop = 0
explanation: Sum of EMFs and IR drops around any closed loop = 0.

prompt: Wheatstone bridge is used to measure:
explanation: Bridge balanced when ratio of resistances match; find unknown R.
At balance, potential across galvanometer is zero.
Resistivity (ρ) is also called specific resistance.
G = 1/R; unit siemens (S).

answers: Very small average velocity in direction of field
explanation: Drift velocity is small; current is due to many electrons.
J = I/A (current per unit area).
Energy = power × time = V I t (or P t).

prompt: Heating effect of current is due to:
explanation: Joule heating: H = I^2 R t (collisions in resistor).

prompt: Electric bulb filament is made of:
explanation: Tungsten has high melting point; glows when hot.

prompt: Why is tungsten used in bulb?
answers: High melting point, can glow at high T
explanation: Withstands high temperature without melting.
Most electrical energy is converted to heat, not light.

prompt: LED is more efficient than incandescent because:
answers: More electrical energy converted to light
explanation: LED converts more energy to visible light.
Short circuit: current bypasses load; very high current.
Earthing provides path for fault current to ground.
MCB trips when current exceeds limit; can be reset.
AC: current (and voltage) change direction periodically.
DC: current flows in one direction.

prompt: Frequency of AC in India is:
explanation: Mains supply in India is 50 Hz AC.
RMS = I_0/√2 for sinusoidal current; equivalent DC for power.
Average power = V_rms I_rms for resistive load.
Transformer needs changing flux; works on AC.
Secondary voltage higher when N_s > N_p.
Secondary voltage lower when N_s < N_p.
Input power = output power (ideal).

prompt: Three-pin plug: third pin is for:
explanation: Third pin is earth (safety).
Live wire carries the supply voltage.
Neutral is earthed; potential ~ 0.
Harm is from current through body (I = V/R).

answers: Very few free electrons (very high R)
explanation: Insulators have very high resistivity.
Conductors have mobile charge carriers.

prompt: Resistance of human body (dry) is of order:
explanation: Dry skin resistance is of order 100 kΩ or more.
Water reduces skin resistance; shock risk increases.
